qas.question: Presbyterians had to distinguished between "Church" and "Meeting house" What was "Church" referring too?
What were churches called before the 19th century?
Early churches were extremely plain, what did most churches not have in them?

answers.text: No stained glass, no elaborate furnishings, and no images

qas.question: What was the building where the images met called?
What did Presbyterians call their churches during the early 19th century?
What did Presbyterians call buildings that were served to worship elaborate furnishings?
What was only inaccessible from the staircase?
What was the centerpiece of the Presbyterian?

context: Early Presbyterians were careful to distinguish between the "church," which referred <a0_0>the members<a0_0/>, and the "<a2_0><b4_0>meeting house<b4_0/><a2_0/>," which was the <a1_0>building<a1_0/> in which the church met. Until the late 19th century, very few Presbyterians ever referred to their buildings as "<b5_0>churches<b5_0/>." Presbyterians believed that <b6_0>meeting-houses (now called churches)<b6_0/> are buildings to support the worship of God. The decor in some instances was austere so as not to detract from worship. Early Presbyterian meeting-houses were extremely plain. <a3_0>No stained glass, no elaborate furnishings, and no images<a3_0/> were to be found in the meeting-house. <b7_0><b8_0>The pulpit<b8_0/><b7_0/>, often raised so as only to be accessible by a staircase, was the centerpiece of the building.
